Hopefully I can schedule if for a day when I'm already off work. The surgeon's office called yesterday and said they just rec'd the PEM scanner machine and they're getting it "put together", like assembling it. When it's ready and functioning, they'll call to schedule the scan. Hmm. I hope they know what they're doing.
Posts.Title: Anyone Had a PEM Scan Before? texasdonna Fearless_One

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2011 07:48PM texasdonna wrote: Just curious, Fearless: why are you waiting till March for the mastectomies? Are you doing chemo first? I was diagnosed in Dec. and had a bilat mastectomy in Jan. ('08), but then I didn't do any chemo or radiation. Will you be doing tissue expanders and reconstruction? Let me know if you have any questions.
Posts.Title: Anyone Had a PEM Scan Before? texasdonna Fearless_One

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2011 11:54AM texasdonna wrote: Thanks, Fearless One. (Love the name!) Glad to know it doesn't hurt and that the pics come out nice and clear. I had dense breasts, too, but they found my initial bc in a digital mammo (my 1st one ever at 42). I feel VERY lucky that my daughter told me to go get a mammo just to have a baseline or things could've been a lot worse down the road. I never felt a lump and neither did my OB/Gyn.
Posts.Title: Anyone Had a PEM Scan Before? texasdonna Fearless_One

Posts.Content: texasdonna wrote: My breast surgeon recommended a PEM (PET Mammogram) for getting a closer look at a nodule near my reconstruction scar under the left breast. I'm wondering what the test entails and why they want to do more testing instead of just removing the nodule and doing a biopsy. It's been there for over a year and shows a kinetic changes. Does anyone else get the feeling that their doctors minimize everything and take a "wait & see" attitude? My surgeon only recommended the PEM after I told her that I refuse to just watch the thing grow for another year. There IS a possibility of the nodule being a local recurrence, isn't there? Dx 12/18/2007, ILC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 1/18/2008 Mastectomy: Left, Right Surgery 7/24/2008 Reconstruction (left); Reconstruction (right) Surgery 10/12/2008 Prophylactic ovary removal Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Anyone Had a PEM Scan Before? texasdonna Fearless_One

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2011 03:33AM texasdonna wrote: That's SO smart, Fearless. I've noticed there's a big anti-mastectomy movement out there, but for some of us gals it's such a big relief not to have to go every 6 months for the mammo and I found it empowering to be able to make that choice with my surgeon (he highly recommended it). After the reconstruction, nobody could even tell I'd had any breast surgery. Same here with the lack of fat. I had skin sparing bmx with TE's for 6 months to stretch the skin and muscle, and then teardrop gummy bear silicone implants. They did the mx incisions around each areola, which you can't even hardly see now, and the implant incisions underneath each breast. I can see those with a mirror, but nobody else can see them even when I wear a bikini. I hope you have the same good fortune and the same peace of mind. That's priceless.
Posts.Title: Anyone Had a PEM Scan Before? texasdonna Fearless_One

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2010 07:10AM texasdonna wrote: Hi and welcome! I think you're user name says it all: what ifs? They can drive us all crazy. The internet is a mixed blessing, with so much info out there at the touch of a keypad. Sometimes, ignorance is bliss, as in my case. I was diagnosed with stage 1 invasive lobular carcinoma at 42 (3 years ago) after my first mammogram. I had never felt a lump, there was no family history, and I didn't have fibrocystic breasts. No bumps, no lumps, no fear. I think it's much worse when you frequently have lumps and don't know how to distinguish when a lump is something to worry about and when it's not. The GOOD news is that you're plugged in with mammography and if you ever do get breast cancer, you'll catch it early. Remember, breast cancer is not a death sentence and we can't let it ruin our lives. I'm a nurse and I was at work in the ICU when the radiologist called me with the diagnosis in 2007. I was in shock for a few seconds, but then I was immediately thankful that my kids were grown and able to fend for themselves, my husband and I had enjoyed a long, happy marriage, and if this was the end of the road for me, so be it. I had a great ride. I hope this helps. You might also read Elizabeth Edwards' book Resilience.
Posts.Title: B9 but still questions what_ifs texasdonna

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2010 06:56AM texasdonna wrote: Thanks for all the info and support! This really helps. I'll push for a biopsy. If they could tell just by looking at CTs and MRIs, we'd never need biopsies, right? I'm thankful for the Christmas season. I'm too busy working all day and doing Christmas baking/shopping at night to get really worried about the nodule/lesion, but you know how it is. Always in the back of your mind. I'll definitely ask for all my records. I actually have the pathology report and the surgery report from the mastectomies, but I'll have my oncologist decipher some of the lingo on Monday when I see her. Thanks again for all the wonderful advice!
Posts.Title: Stage, Grade, & OncotypeDx texasdonna Lee7

Posts.Content: texasdonna wrote: I just realized that I don't know my grade or OncotypeDx and I was diagnosed with ILC 3 years ago. Is this info that your oncologist usually gives you? Also, how do you get a PET scan? Do they ever do one on someone with stage 1 breast cancer? I had a bilateral mastectomy in 2008, but now there's a nodule on my left lower outer breast at the chest wall. The radiologist says to watch it for 6 months and then get an ultrasound. Are they crazy? I'm going to see my oncologist Monday. The MRI report said "rapid washout" which is usually associated with malignancy, so why would anyone want to just wait and watch? Ugh! It's so frustrating to hear that "it's probably benign" or "it probably won't ever come back". If we only considered "probably", then I probably wouldn't have gotten breast cancer at 42 when it doesn't run in my family. Sorry. Venting. Does anyone know how I can find out my grade of cancer or my OncotypeDx if they didn't run a  genetic test on my pathology report? Dx 12/18/2007, ILC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 1/18/2008 Mastectomy: Left, Right Surgery 7/24/2008 Reconstruction (left); Reconstruction (right) Surgery 10/12/2008 Prophylactic ovary removal Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Stage, Grade, & OncotypeDx texasdonna Lee7

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2010 07:55AM texasdonna wrote: I forgot to mentiion that this was the 2nd MRI I've had that showed the nodule. The 1st one was a year ago, but nobody told me about the nodule. The radiologist and my family doc both said everything was fine. Negative. I didn't ask for a copy of the report until a few weeks ago at my chiropractor's request. Thank goodness for her. I went for all the tests last Nov/Dec (bone scan, MRI, plain films) in the first place because of left breast pain....The breast pain has never gone away. For a year and a half, shooting pain through the front side at the nipple straight through to the shoulder blade. Not debilitating. Just there several times a day every day. The docs were thinking scar tissue or mastectomy pain (like the underlying muscle)...With this new MRI showing changes in kinetic activity from a plateau to a "rapid washout", I'm not taking any chances. The docs have taught me not to trust them. If you google "rapid washout", you learn that it's usually associated with malignancy. I'm not sure why they'd want to wait 6 months to take another look at that instead of doing a biopsy, but I'm not waiting around. I'll get new docs if I have to.
Posts.Title: Stage, Grade, & OncotypeDx texasdonna Lee7

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2010 08:13PM texasdonna wrote: Wow. I'm so glad to see all the different outcomes and bumps in the road with you guys. I thought my cancer was long gone after almost 3 years, but now there's a nodule on my left lower breast at the chest wall. Hopefully it's a benign little growth, but I'm seeing the oncologist tomorrow to see if I can have it biopsied. It's so comforting to know that even if it turns out to be malignant, I've got this site and all of you to look to for support.
Posts.Title: Stage 1 and Mets mari65 barbe1958

Posts.Content: Dec 25, 2010 11:26AM texasdonna wrote: Wow. Sorry you gals are all having to go through this at the holidays, too.  I was diagnosed on Dec. 18, 2007 with ILC after my 1st ever mammogram at age 42.  No lump, no family history. Just an area of dense tissue that showed up on the mammo. My surgeon recommended bilateral mastectomy because the ILC often mirrors in the other breast, and I'm glad I did that because the pathology report showed several different formations of LCIS in both breasts, in addition to the ILC tumor in the right breast. I didn't have the OncotypeDx, but my MIB-1 score was high at 22. I don't know if they do that test in lieu of the oncotype or if my insurance refused to pay for the oncotype.  I was probably too quiet and trusting at the time and I didn't know about this website to learn from other women with breast cancer. Mine was caught early, at stage 1, thank goodness, with a negative sentinel node biopsy, so I only have to do Tamoxifen for 5 years. I had tissue expanders for 6 months, and then silicone implants which all went very smoothly with no infections or complications. The JP drains and the chest heaviness were the toughest parts for me, but it only lasted a couple of weeks. You guys are way ahead of the game by using this site for support. Good luck and Merry Christmas!
Posts.Title: Stage, Grade, & OncotypeDx texasdonna Lee7

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2011 10:59AM texasdonna wrote: So true about not remembering ANYTHING! I had an excisional biopsy Friday morning and didn't have any memory of the procedure either. It's the coctail of anesthesia they give us. Good stuff. Versed, Propofol (the Michael Jackson drug), and Fentanyl (a pain killer). At least that's what they gave me. My surgeon told me she'd hear back from the lab Monday or Tuesday. Yours taking 2 weeks would be a nightmare. That's how long it took for me to hear back with the mastectomy pathology report, but I guess the simple biopsy path is much quicker. Good luck to you! I hope it's benign!
